articles.headline: Red-Hot Web in China Richly Rewards Foreign Investors
articles.snippet: The lucrative returns have raised concerns that China could tighten restrictions to ensure control over one of the most dynamic parts of its economy.
articles.abstract: The lucrative returns have raised concerns that China could tighten restrictions to ensure control over one of the most dynamic parts of its economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China – It is one of the best investments of the digital age.

articles.headline: Off the Record in a Chat App? Don’t Be Sure
articles.snippet: The popular mobile service, Snapchat, agreed to settle charges by the Federal Trade Commission that messages sent through its app did not disappear as easily as promised.
articles.abstract: The popular mobile service, Snapchat, agreed to settle charges by the Federal Trade Commission that messages sent through its app did not disappear as easily as promised.
articles.lead_paragraph: What happens on the Internet stays on the Internet.

articles.headline: Holding Auditors Accountable on Reports
articles.snippet: New rules in Britain require auditors to comment on particular risks companies face and to say what they did to deal with those risks, as well as discuss how much of the company they actually audited.
articles.abstract: New rules in Britain require auditors to comment on particular risks companies face and to say what they did to deal with those risks, as well as discuss how much of the company they actually audited.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rolls-Royce — the jet engine maker, not the car company — used estimates and assumptions in its financial results that resulted in “mildly cautious profit recognition” in an important part of its business. On the other hand, the company was “mildly optimistic” in other assumptions, “resulting in a somewhat lower liability being recorded than might otherwise have been the case.”

articles.headline: Apple Said to Be in Talks to Buy Rising Music Brand for $3.2 Billion
articles.snippet: A deal for Beats Electronics could signal an effort by Apple to transform its approach to music more than a decade after it opened the iTunes download store.
articles.abstract: A deal for Beats Electronics could signal an effort by Apple to transform its approach to music more than a decade after it opened the iTunes download store.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple is in discussions to buy Beats Electronics, the company behind the popular Beats by Dr. Dre headphones, for $3.2 billion, according to people briefed on the talks, in what would be the biggest acquisition in Apple’s history.
articles.byline: By Ben Sisario, Brian X. Chen and David Gelles

articles.headline: At Odds, Omnicom and Publicis End Merger
articles.snippet: The ad giants called off their $35 billion merger, bringing a premature end to a deal that would have created the largest advertising company in the world.
articles.abstract: The ad giants called off their $35 billion merger, bringing a premature end to a deal that would have created the largest advertising company in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ad giants Omnicom Group and Publicis Groupe called off their $35 billion merger on Thursday, bringing a premature end to a deal that would have created the largest advertising company in the world.

articles.headline: Recalled Used Cars Roam the Roads as Federal Legislation Stalls
articles.snippet: Dealers contend that not all recalls require immediate attention, though regulators say recalls, by definition, involve pressing safety concerns.
articles.abstract: Dealers contend that not all recalls require immediate attention, though regulators say recalls, by definition, involve pressing safety concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Clayton was driving 70 miles an hour in his Ram 1500 pickup truck last October when he learned the hard way that it had a serious safety problem. The rear axle locked up, causing him to nearly lose control before wrestling the truck to the side of the highway.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Christopher Jensen

articles.headline: Deadly Illness in Nicaragua Baffles Experts
articles.snippet: Across Central America, a kidney disease has killed at least 20,000 people over a decade and is so poorly understood that it does not have a universally agreed upon name.
articles.abstract: Across Central America, a kidney disease has killed at least 20,000 people over a decade and is so poorly understood that it does not have a universally agreed upon name.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICHIGALPA, Nicaragua — During the harvest season, when exhausted workers spend seven days a week cutting sugar cane, the signs of illness were hard to spot at first.

articles.headline: From Crimea, Putin Trumpets Mother Russia
articles.snippet: The Russian president traveled to Sevastopol, where he used the anniversary of victory over the Nazis to assert that Moscow had the right to annex the peninsula.
articles.abstract: The Russian president traveled to Sevastopol, where he used the anniversary of victory over the Nazis to assert that Moscow had the right to annex the peninsula.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Putting his personal seal on the annexation of Crimea, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia traveled on Friday to the naval port of Sevastopol, where he used the anniversary of the victory over Nazi Germany to assert that Moscow had the right to take over the Black Sea peninsula.

articles.headline: Four Stand-Out College Essays About Money
articles.snippet: Looking to the future, high school seniors can draw revealing portraits in writing about their financial circumstances.
articles.abstract: Looking to the future, high school seniors can draw revealing portraits in writing about their financial circumstances.
articles.lead_paragraph: Talking about money is hard. Writing well about yourself may be harder still. So trying to do both at once, as a teenager, while addressing complete strangers who control your future, would seem to be foolhardy.
